sentences.zh: 自古受命帝王，曷嘗不封禪？

translations.text: Since ancient times, have the emperors and kings who received the mandate of heaven ever failed to perform the feng and shan sacrifices?

sentences.zh: 蓋有無其應而用事者矣，未有睹符瑞見而不臻乎泰山者也。

translations.text: There have been cases where they performed the rituals without receiving the appropriate omens, but never have there been cases where auspicious signs appeared and they did not proceed to Mount Tai.

sentences.zh: 雖受命而功不至，至梁父矣而德不洽，洽矣而日有不暇給，是以即事用希。

translations.text: Even those who received the mandate but whose achievements were insufficient, or those who reached Mount Li but whose virtue was not all-encompassing, or those whose virtue was all-encompassing but who lacked sufficient time - these are the reasons why the rituals were performed rarely.

sentences.zh: 傳曰：「三年不為禮，禮必廢；

translations.text: The Classic says: 'If for three years the rites are not performed, the rites will surely be abolished;

sentences.zh: 三年不為樂，樂必壞。」

translations.text: if for three years the music is not performed, the music will surely be ruined.'

sentences.zh: 每世之隆，則封禪答焉，及衰而息。

translations.text: In times of flourishing dynasties, the feng and shan sacrifices respond accordingly; in times of decline, they cease.

sentences.zh: 厥曠遠者千有餘載，近者數百載，故其儀闕然堙滅，其詳不可得而記聞云。

translations.text: The longest gaps lasted over a thousand years, the shortest several hundred years, so their ceremonies have become lost and obscured, and their details can no longer be recorded or transmitted.

Since ancient times, have the emperors and kings who received the mandate of heaven ever failed to perform the feng and shan sacrifices? There have been cases where they performed the rituals without receiving the appropriate omens, but never have there been cases where auspicious signs appeared and they did not proceed to Mount Tai. Even those who received the mandate but whose achievements were insufficient, or those who reached Mount Li but whose virtue was not all-encompassing, or those whose virtue was all-encompassing but who lacked sufficient time - these are the reasons why the rituals were performed rarely. The Classic says: 'If for three years the rites are not performed, the rites will surely be abolished; if for three years the music is not performed, the music will surely be ruined.' In times of flourishing dynasties, the feng and shan sacrifices respond accordingly; in times of decline, they cease. The longest gaps lasted over a thousand years, the shortest several hundred years, so their ceremonies have become lost and obscured, and their details can no longer be recorded or transmitted.

sentences.zh: 自周克殷後十四世，世益衰，禮樂廢，諸侯恣行，而幽王為犬戎所敗，周東徙雒邑。

translations.text: Duke Mu died in his thirty-ninth year.

In the ninth year of Duke Mu of Qin's reign, after Duke Huan of Qi became hegemon, he assembled the feudal lords at Kuiqiu and wished to perform the feng and shan sacrifices. Guan Zhong said: 'In ancient times, those who performed the feng sacrifice on Mount Tai and the shan sacrifice on Mount Li numbered seventy-two houses, and I have recorded twelve of them. In ancient times, the Wu Huai clan performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Yunyun; Fu Xi performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Yunyun; Shen Nong performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Yunyun; Yan Di performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Yunyun; Huang Di performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Tingting; Zhuan Xu performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Yunyun; Di Ku performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Yunyun; Yao performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Yunyun; Shun performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Yunyun; Yu performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Kuaiji; Tang performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Yunyun; King Cheng of Zhou performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Sheshou: all received the mandate before they could perform feng and shan.' Duke Huan said: 'I have attacked the Shan Rong in the north, passing through Gu Zhu; attacked Da Xia in the west, crossed the Flowing Sands, tied horses and hung carriages, ascended Mount Bei'er; attacked south to Zhaoling, ascended Mount Xiong'er to gaze upon the Yangtze and Han rivers. I have assembled chariots three times, assembled carriages six times, united the feudal lords nine times, corrected the realm once, and no feudal lord dares disobey me. How is this different from when the Three Dynasties received the mandate?' Therefore Guan Zhong, seeing that Duke Huan could not be persuaded with words, set forth practical reasons, saying: 'The ancient feng and shan sacrifices used millet from Xiang Shang, grain from Bei Li, which served as the abundance; between the Yangtze and Huai rivers, one thatched hut with three ridges, which served as the mat. The Eastern Sea brought forth the fish with united eyes, the Western Sea brought forth the birds with united wings, and then there were fifteen things that came without being summoned. Now phoenixes and unicorns do not come, auspicious grains do not grow, but thorns and brambles flourish, owls appear frequently, and yet you wish to perform feng and shan - is this not impossible?' Therefore Duke Huan stopped. That year, Duke Mu of Qin welcomed the Jin lord Yi Wu. Afterward he installed three Jin rulers and pacified their disorders. Duke Mu died in his thirty-ninth year.

sentences.zh: 其後百有餘年，而孔子論述六藝，傳略言易姓而王，封泰山禪乎梁父者七十餘王矣，其俎豆之禮不章，蓋難言之。

translations.text: More than a hundred years later, Confucius discussed and transmitted the Six Arts, briefly saying that those who changed surnames and became kings, performing feng on Mount Tai and shan on Mount Li, numbered more than seventy kings, but their sacrificial rituals were not clear, so it is difficult to speak of them.

sentences.zh: 或問禘之說，孔子曰：「不知。

translations.text: Someone asked about the explanation of the di sacrifice, and Confucius said: 'I do not know.

sentences.zh: 知禘之說，其於天下也視其掌。」

translations.text: If one knew the explanation of the di sacrifice, it would be like seeing the whole realm in the palm of the hand.'

sentences.zh: 詩云紂在位，文王受命，政不及泰山。

translations.text: The Poetry says: 'When Zhou was on the throne, King Wen received the mandate, but his administration did not reach Mount Tai.'

sentences.zh: 武王克殷二年，天下未寧而崩。

translations.text: King Wu conquered Yin in the second year, but the realm was not yet peaceful when he died.

sentences.zh: 爰周德之洽維成王，成王之封禪則近之矣。

translations.text: Only during King Cheng's time was Zhou virtue fully pervasive, and King Cheng's feng and shan was close to it.

sentences.zh: 及後陪臣執政，季氏旅於泰山，仲尼譏之。

translations.text: When later ministers took power, the Ji clan traveled to Mount Tai, and Confucius criticized them.

sentences.zh: 是時萇弘以方事周靈王，諸侯莫朝周，周力少，萇弘乃明鬼神事，設射貍首。

translations.text: At this time, Chang Hong used magical arts to serve King Ling of Zhou, and the feudal lords did not come to court Zhou, so Zhou power was weak. Chang Hong then made clear the affairs of ghosts and spirits, and set up the shooting of fox heads.

sentences.zh: 貍首者，諸侯之不來者。

translations.text: Fox heads were for the feudal lords who did not come.

sentences.zh: 依物怪欲以致諸侯。

translations.text: He relied on strange things to try to bring the feudal lords.

sentences.zh: 諸侯不從，而晉人執殺萇弘。

translations.text: The feudal lords did not follow, and the Jin people captured and killed Chang Hong.

sentences.zh: 周人之言方怪者自萇弘。

translations.text: The Zhou people's discussions of magical oddities began with Chang Hong.

sentences.zh: 其後百餘年，秦靈公作吳陽上畤，祭黃帝；

translations.text: More than a hundred years later, Duke Ling of Qin built the Wu Yang Upper Altar, sacrificing to the Yellow Emperor;

sentences.zh: 作下畤，祭炎帝。

translations.text: built the Lower Altar, sacrificing to the Yan Emperor.

sentences.zh: 後四十八年，周太史儋見秦獻公曰：「秦始與周合，合而離，五百歲當復合，合十七年而霸王出焉。」

translations.text: Forty-eight years later, the Zhou Grand Historian Tan met Duke Xian of Qin and said: 'Qin initially merged with Zhou, merged then separated, after five hundred years they should merge again, merge for seventeen years and a hegemon king will emerge.'

sentences.zh: 櫟陽雨金，秦獻公自以為得金瑞，故作畦畤櫟陽而祀白帝。

translations.text: It rained gold at Yueyang, and Duke Xian of Qin considered himself to have obtained the gold omen, so he built the Qi Altar at Yueyang and sacrificed to the White Emperor.

Forty-eight years later, the Zhou Grand Historian Tan met Duke Xian of Qin and said: 'Qin initially merged with Zhou, merged then separated, after five hundred years they should merge again, merge for seventeen years and a hegemon king will emerge.' It rained gold at Yueyang, and Duke Xian of Qin considered himself to have obtained the gold omen, so he built the Qi Altar at Yueyang and sacrificed to the White Emperor.

sentences.zh: 其後百二十歲而秦滅周，周之九鼎入于秦。

translations.text: One hundred twenty years later Qin extinguished Zhou, and Zhou's nine tripods entered Qin.

sentences.zh: 或曰宋太丘社亡，而鼎沒于泗水彭城下。

translations.text: Some say the Song Taiqiu Altar perished, and the tripods sank in the Si River beneath Pengcheng.

sentences.zh: 其後百一十五年而秦并天下。

translations.text: One hundred fifteen years later Qin unified the realm.
One hundred fifteen years later Qin unified the realm.

sentences.zh: 秦始皇既并天下而帝，或曰：「黃帝得土德，黃龍地螾見。

translations.text: After Qin Shi Huang unified the realm and became emperor, some said: 'The Yellow Emperor obtained earth virtue, yellow dragons and earthworms appeared.

sentences.zh: 夏得木德，青龍止於郊，草木暢茂。

translations.text: Xia obtained wood virtue, green dragons stopped in the suburbs, grass and trees flourished.

sentences.zh: 殷得金德，銀自山溢。

translations.text: Yin obtained metal virtue, silver overflowed from the mountains.

sentences.zh: 周得火德，有赤烏之符。

translations.text: Zhou obtained fire virtue, there were symbols of red crows.

sentences.zh: 今秦變周，水德之時。

translations.text: Now Qin changes Zhou, it is the time of water virtue.

sentences.zh: 昔秦文公出獵，獲黑龍，此其水德之瑞。」

translations.text: Formerly Duke Wen of Qin went hunting and obtained a black dragon, this is the omen of water virtue.'

sentences.zh: 於是秦更命河曰「德水」，以冬十月為年首，色上黑，度以六為名，音上大呂，事統上法。

translations.text: Therefore Qin renamed the river 'Virtue River', made the tenth month of winter the beginning of the year, took black as the superior color, measured with six as the name, took Da Lü as the superior pitch, and affairs were governed by law.

After Qin Shi Huang unified the realm and became emperor, some said: 'The Yellow Emperor obtained earth virtue, yellow dragons and earthworms appeared. Xia obtained wood virtue, green dragons stopped in the suburbs, grass and trees flourished. Yin obtained metal virtue, silver overflowed from the mountains. Zhou obtained fire virtue, there were symbols of red crows. Now Qin changes Zhou, it is the time of water virtue. Formerly Duke Wen of Qin went hunting and obtained a black dragon, this is the omen of water virtue.' Therefore Qin renamed the river 'Virtue River', made the tenth month of winter the beginning of the year, took black as the superior color, measured with six as the name, took Da Lü as the superior pitch, and affairs were governed by law.

sentences.zh: 即帝位三年，東巡郡縣，祠騶嶧山，頌秦功業。

translations.text: In the third year of his imperial position, he toured east through the commanderies and counties, sacrificed at Zouyi Mountain, praising Qin's achievements.

sentences.zh: 於是徵從齊魯之儒生博士七十人，至乎泰山下。

translations.text: Therefore he summoned seventy Confucian scholars and doctors from Qi and Lu to the foot of Mount Tai.

sentences.zh: 諸儒生或議曰：「古者封禪為蒲車，惡傷山之土石草木；

translations.text: Some Confucian scholars discussed: 'In ancient times, for the feng sacrifice they used cattail wagons to avoid harming the mountain's soil, stones, and vegetation;

sentences.zh: 埽地而祭，席用葅稭，言其易遵也。」

translations.text: they swept the ground and sacrificed, using mats of straw, speaking of how easy it was to follow.'

sentences.zh: 始皇聞此議各乖異，難施用，由此絀儒生。

translations.text: Shi Huang heard these discussions were all different, difficult to implement, so he dismissed the Confucian scholars.

sentences.zh: 而遂除車道，上自泰山陽至巔，立石頌秦始皇帝德，明其得封也。

translations.text: He then cleared the road, ascending from the sunny side of Mount Tai to the peak, erected a stone to praise Qin Shi Huang's virtue, making clear that he obtained the feng sacrifice.

sentences.zh: 從陰道下，禪於梁父。

translations.text: From the shady path he descended, performing shan at Mount Li.

sentences.zh: 其禮頗采太祝之祀雍上帝所用，而封藏皆祕之，世不得而記也。

translations.text: The rituals mostly adopted what the Grand Invocator used in sacrificing to the Supreme Deity at Yong, but the feng and shan details were all kept secret, so later generations could not record them.

In the third year of his imperial position, he toured east through the commanderies and counties, sacrificed at Zouyi Mountain, praising Qin's achievements. Therefore he summoned seventy Confucian scholars and doctors from Qi and Lu to the foot of Mount Tai. Some Confucian scholars discussed: 'In ancient times, for the feng sacrifice they used cattail wagons to avoid harming the mountain's soil, stones, and vegetation; they swept the ground and sacrificed, using mats of straw, speaking of how easy it was to follow.' Shi Huang heard these discussions were all different, difficult to implement, so he dismissed the Confucian scholars. He then cleared the road, ascending from the sunny side of Mount Tai to the peak, erected a stone to praise Qin Shi Huang's virtue, making clear that he obtained the feng sacrifice. From the shady path he descended, performing shan at Mount Li. The rituals mostly adopted what the Grand Invocator used in sacrificing to the Supreme Deity at Yong, but the feng and shan details were all kept secret, so later generations could not record them.

sentences.zh: 始皇之上泰山，中阪遇暴風雨，休於大樹下。

translations.text: When Shi Huang ascended Mount Tai, midway he encountered violent wind and rain, and rested under a large tree.

sentences.zh: 諸儒生既絀，不得與用於封事之禮，聞始皇遇風雨，則譏之。

translations.text: The Confucian scholars, having been dismissed, could not participate in the feng sacrifice rituals. Hearing that Shi Huang encountered wind and rain, they mocked him.

When Shi Huang ascended Mount Tai, midway he encountered violent wind and rain, and rested under a large tree. The Confucian scholars, having been dismissed, could not participate in the feng sacrifice rituals. Hearing that Shi Huang encountered wind and rain, they mocked him.

sentences.zh: 於是始皇遂東遊海上，行禮祠名山大川及八神，求僊人羨門之屬。

translations.text: Therefore Shi Huang then toured east to the sea, performing rituals and sacrifices to famous mountains, great rivers, and the eight spirits, seeking immortals and the like of Xianmen.

sentences.zh: 八神將自古而有之，或曰太公以來作之。

translations.text: The eight spirits have existed since ancient times, some say they were created since the time of Tai Gong.

sentences.zh: 齊所以為齊，以天齊也。

translations.text: What makes Qi Qi is the heavenly Qi.

sentences.zh: 其祀絕莫知起時。

translations.text: When its sacrifices ceased, no one knows when they began.

sentences.zh: 八神：一曰天主，祠天齊。

translations.text: The eight spirits: the first is the Heaven Lord, sacrificing to Tian Qi.

sentences.zh: 天齊淵水，居臨菑南郊山下者。

translations.text: Tian Qi is a deep pool, located below the mountain in the southern suburbs of Linzi.

sentences.zh: 二曰地主，祠泰山梁父。

translations.text: The second is the Earth Lord, sacrificing at Mount Tai and Mount Li.

sentences.zh: 蓋天好陰，祠之必於高山之下，小山之上，命曰「畤」；

translations.text: Heaven prefers shade, so sacrifices to it must be at the foot of high mountains and on top of small mountains, called 'zhi';

sentences.zh: 地貴陽，祭之必於澤中圜丘云。

translations.text: earth prefers sunlight, so sacrifices to it must be in round mounds in marshes.

sentences.zh: 三曰兵主，祠蚩尤。

translations.text: The third is the War Lord, sacrificing to Chi You.

sentences.zh: 蚩尤在東平陸監鄉，齊之西境也。

translations.text: Chi You is in Dongping Lu Jian Township, the western border of Qi.

sentences.zh: 四曰陰主，祠三山。

translations.text: The fourth is the Yin Lord, sacrificing to the Three Mountains.

sentences.zh: 五曰陽主，祠之罘。

translations.text: The fifth is the Yang Lord, sacrificing at Fu.

sentences.zh: 六曰月主，祠之萊山。

translations.text: The sixth is the Moon Lord, sacrificing at Mount Lai.

sentences.zh: 皆在齊北，并勃海。

translations.text: All are north of Qi, bordering the Bohai Sea.

sentences.zh: 七曰日主，祠成山。

translations.text: The seventh is the Sun Lord, sacrificing at Mount Cheng.

sentences.zh: 成山斗入海，最居齊東北隅，以迎日出云。

translations.text: Mount Cheng thrusts into the sea, located at the northeastern corner of Qi, to welcome the sunrise.

sentences.zh: 八曰四時主，祠瑯邪。

translations.text: The eighth is the Four Seasons Lord, sacrificing at Langye.

sentences.zh: 瑯邪在齊東方，蓋歲之所始。

translations.text: Langye is in the eastern part of Qi, probably where the year begins.

sentences.zh: 皆各用一牢具祠，而巫祝所損益，珪幣雜異焉。

translations.text: All use one set of sacrificial animals for each sacrifice, but the shamans and invokers made additions and subtractions, with varying jade and silk offerings.

Therefore Shi Huang then toured east to the sea, performing rituals and sacrifices to famous mountains, great rivers, and the eight spirits, seeking immortals and the like of Xianmen. When its sacrifices ceased, no one knows when they began. The eight spirits: the first is the Heaven Lord, sacrificing to Tian Qi. Tian Qi is a deep pool, located below the mountain in the southern suburbs of Linzi. The second is the Earth Lord, sacrificing at Mount Tai and Mount Li. Heaven prefers shade, so sacrifices to it must be at the foot of high mountains and on top of small mountains, called 'zhi'; earth prefers sunlight, so sacrifices to it must be in round mounds in marshes. The third is the War Lord, sacrificing to Chi You. Chi You is in Dongping Lu Jian Township, the western border of Qi. The fourth is the Yin Lord, sacrificing to the Three Mountains. The fifth is the Yang Lord, sacrificing at Fu. The sixth is the Moon Lord, sacrificing at Mount Lai. All are north of Qi, bordering the Bohai Sea. The seventh is the Sun Lord, sacrificing at Mount Cheng. Mount Cheng thrusts into the sea, located at the northeastern corner of Qi, to welcome the sunrise. The eighth is the Four Seasons Lord, sacrificing at Langye. Langye is in the eastern part of Qi, probably where the year begins. All use one set of sacrificial animals for each sacrifice, but the shamans and invokers made additions and subtractions, with varying jade and silk offerings.

sentences.zh: 自齊威、宣之時，騶子之徒論著終始五德之運，及秦帝而齊人奏之，故始皇采用之。

translations.text: From the time of Duke Wei and Duke Xuan of Qi, Zou Zi's followers discussed and wrote about the cycles of the beginning and end of the five virtues. When Qin became emperor, the Qi people presented it, so Shi Huang adopted it.

sentences.zh: 而宋毋忌、正伯僑、充尚、羨門高最後皆燕人，為方僊道，形解銷化，依於鬼神之事。

translations.text: Song Wuji, Zheng Boqiao, Chong Shang, Xianmen Gao were the last, all Yan people, practicing the way of immortals, bodily dissolution and transformation, relying on the affairs of ghosts and spirits.

sentences.zh: 騶衍以陰陽主運顯於諸侯，而燕齊海上之方士傳其術不能通，然則怪迂阿諛茍合之徒自此興，不可勝數也。

translations.text: Zou Yan became prominent among the feudal lords by mastering yin and yang, and the magicians along the Qi and Yan coasts transmitted his techniques but could not master them thoroughly. Nevertheless, the strange, far-fetched, flattering, and compromising followers arose from this, too numerous to count.

From the time of Duke Wei and Duke Xuan of Qi, Zou Zi's followers discussed and wrote about the cycles of the beginning and end of the five virtues. When Qin became emperor, the Qi people presented it, so Shi Huang adopted it. Song Wuji, Zheng Boqiao, Chong Shang, Xianmen Gao were the last, all Yan people, practicing the way of immortals, bodily dissolution and transformation, relying on the affairs of ghosts and spirits. Zou Yan became prominent among the feudal lords by mastering yin and yang, and the magicians along the Qi and Yan coasts transmitted his techniques but could not master them thoroughly. Nevertheless, the strange, far-fetched, flattering, and compromising followers arose from this, too numerous to count.

sentences.zh: 自威、宣、燕昭使人入海求蓬萊、方丈、瀛洲。

translations.text: From the time of Wei, Xuan, and Yan Zhao, they sent people into the sea to seek Penglai, Fangzhang, and Yingzhou.

sentences.zh: 此三神山者，其傅在勃海中，去人不遠；

translations.text: These three divine mountains, according to tradition, are in the Bohai Sea, not far from people;

sentences.zh: 患且至，則船風引而去。

translations.text: but when about to arrive, the wind blows the ships away.

sentences.zh: 蓋嘗有至者，諸僊人及不死之藥皆在焉。

translations.text: It is said that those who have reached them find immortals and medicines of immortality there.

sentences.zh: 其物禽獸盡白，而黃金銀為宮闕。

translations.text: Their birds and beasts are all white, and palaces are made of gold and silver.

sentences.zh: 未至，望之如雲；

translations.text: Before arriving, they appear like clouds;

sentences.zh: 及到，三神山反居水下。

translations.text: when arriving, the three divine mountains sink below the water.

sentences.zh: 臨之，風輒引去，終莫能至云。

translations.text: When approaching them, the wind always blows them away, and in the end no one can reach them.

sentences.zh: 世主莫不甘心焉。

translations.text: Every ruler has been devoted to them.

sentences.zh: 及至秦始皇并天下，至海上，則方士言之不可勝數。

translations.text: When Qin Shi Huang unified the realm and reached the sea, the magicians' words were too numerous to count.

sentences.zh: 始皇自以為至海上而恐不及矣，使人乃齎童男女入海求之。

translations.text: Shi Huang considered himself to have reached the sea but feared he might not reach the mountains, so he sent people carrying boys and girls into the sea to seek them.

sentences.zh: 船交海中，皆以風為解，曰未能至，望見之焉。

translations.text: The ships met in the sea, all using wind as an excuse, saying they could not reach them but had glimpsed them.

sentences.zh: 其明年，始皇復游海上，至瑯邪，過恒山，從上黨歸。

translations.text: The next year, Shi Huang toured the sea again, reaching Langye, passing Mount Heng, returning from Shangdang.

sentences.zh: 後三年，游碣石，考入海方士，從上郡歸。

translations.text: Three years later, he toured Mount Jie, examined the sea-going magicians, returned from Shang Commandery.

sentences.zh: 後五年，始皇南至湘山，遂登會稽，并海上，冀遇海中三神山之奇藥。

translations.text: Five years later, Shi Huang went south to Mount Xiang, then ascended Mount Kuaiji, toured along the sea, hoping to encounter the marvelous medicines of the three divine mountains in the sea.

sentences.zh: 不得，還至沙丘崩。

translations.text: He did not obtain them, and on his return he collapsed at Shaqiu.

From the time of Wei, Xuan, and Yan Zhao, they sent people into the sea to seek Penglai, Fangzhang, and Yingzhou. These three divine mountains, according to tradition, are in the Bohai Sea, not far from people; but when about to arrive, the wind blows the ships away. It is said that those who have reached them find immortals and medicines of immortality there. Their birds and beasts are all white, and palaces are made of gold and silver. Before arriving, they appear like clouds; when arriving, the three divine mountains sink below the water. When approaching them, the wind always blows them away, and in the end no one can reach them. Every ruler has been devoted to them. When Qin Shi Huang unified the realm and reached the sea, the magicians' words were too numerous to count. Shi Huang considered himself to have reached the sea but feared he might not reach the mountains, so he sent people carrying boys and girls into the sea to seek them. The ships met in the sea, all using wind as an excuse, saying they could not reach them but had glimpsed them. The next year, Shi Huang toured the sea again, reaching Langye, passing Mount Heng, returning from Shangdang. Three years later, he toured Mount Jie, examined the sea-going magicians, returned from Shang Commandery. Five years later, Shi Huang went south to Mount Xiang, then ascended Mount Kuaiji, toured along the sea, hoping to encounter the marvelous medicines of the three divine mountains in the sea. He did not obtain them, and on his return he collapsed at Shaqiu.

sentences.zh: 二世元年，東巡碣石，并海南，歷泰山，至會稽，皆禮祠之，而刻勒始皇所立石書旁，以章始皇之功德。

translations.text: In the first year of the Second Emperor, he toured east to Mount Jie, toured south of the sea, passed Mount Tai, reached Mount Kuaiji, all performing rituals and sacrifices, and carved beside the stone inscriptions Shi Huang had erected, to proclaim Shi Huang's achievements and virtue.

sentences.zh: 其秋，諸侯畔秦。

translations.text: That autumn, the feudal lords rebelled against Qin.

sentences.zh: 三年而二世弒死。

translations.text: After three years, the Second Emperor was assassinated and died.

In the first year of the Second Emperor, he toured east to Mount Jie, toured south of the sea, passed Mount Tai, reached Mount Kuaiji, all performing rituals and sacrifices, and carved beside the stone inscriptions Shi Huang had erected, to proclaim Shi Huang's achievements and virtue. That autumn, the feudal lords rebelled against Qin. After three years, the Second Emperor was assassinated and died.

sentences.zh: 始皇封禪之後十二歲，秦亡。

translations.text: Twelve years after Shi Huang's feng and shan sacrifices, Qin perished.

sentences.zh: 諸儒生疾秦焚詩書，誅僇文學，百姓怨其法，天下畔之，皆訛曰：「始皇上泰山，為暴風雨所擊，不得封禪。」

translations.text: The Confucian scholars resented Qin for burning the poems and books, slaughtering the literati, and the people resented their laws, so the realm rebelled against them, all falsely saying: 'Shi Huang ascended Mount Tai, was struck by violent wind and rain, could not perform the feng and shan.'

sentences.zh: 此豈所謂無其德而用事者邪？

translations.text: Is this not what is called performing the rituals without possessing virtue?

Twelve years after Shi Huang's feng and shan sacrifices, Qin perished. The Confucian scholars resented Qin for burning the poems and books, slaughtering the literati, and the people resented their laws, so the realm rebelled against them, all falsely saying: 'Shi Huang ascended Mount Tai, was struck by violent wind and rain, could not perform the feng and shan.' Is this not what is called performing the rituals without possessing virtue?

sentences.zh: 昔三代之（君）［居］皆在河洛之閒，故嵩高為中嶽，而四嶽各如其方，四瀆咸在山東。

translations.text: In ancient times, the capitals of the Three Dynasties were all between the Yellow River and Luo River, so Mount Song was the central peak, and the four peaks were each in their directions, and the four rivers were all east of the mountains.

sentences.zh: 至秦稱帝，都咸陽，則五嶽、四瀆皆并在東方。

translations.text: When Qin declared itself emperor and made Xianyang the capital, then the five peaks and four rivers were all in the east.

sentences.zh: 自五帝以至秦，軼興軼衰，名山大川或在諸侯，或在天子，其禮損益世殊，不可勝記。

translations.text: From the Five Emperors to Qin, dynasties rose and declined alternately, famous mountains and great rivers were sometimes in the feudal lords' territories, sometimes in the Son of Heaven's domain, their rituals increased and decreased with each generation, impossible to record completely.

sentences.zh: 及秦并天下，令祠官所常奉天地名山大川鬼神可得而序也。

translations.text: When Qin unified the realm, they ordered the sacrificial officials to constantly maintain the sacrifices to heaven, earth, famous mountains, great rivers, and ghosts and spirits that could be properly ordered.

In ancient times, the capitals of the Three Dynasties were all between the Yellow River and Luo River, so Mount Song was the central peak, and the four peaks were each in their directions, and the four rivers were all east of the mountains. When Qin declared itself emperor and made Xianyang the capital, then the five peaks and four rivers were all in the east. From the Five Emperors to Qin, dynasties rose and declined alternately, famous mountains and great rivers were sometimes in the feudal lords' territories, sometimes in the Son of Heaven's domain, their rituals increased and decreased with each generation, impossible to record completely. When Qin unified the realm, they ordered the sacrificial officials to constantly maintain the sacrifices to heaven, earth, famous mountains, great rivers, and ghosts and spirits that could be properly ordered.

sentences.zh: 於是自殽以東，名山五，大川祠二。

translations.text: Therefore, east of Xiao, five famous mountains and two great rivers were sacrificed to.

sentences.zh: 曰太室。

translations.text: Called Tai Shi.

sentences.zh: 太室，嵩高也。

translations.text: Tai Shi is Mount Song.

sentences.zh: 恒山，泰山，會稽，湘山。

translations.text: Mount Heng, Mount Tai, Mount Kuaiji, Mount Xiang.

sentences.zh: 水曰濟，曰淮。

translations.text: Rivers called Ji, called Huai.

sentences.zh: 春以脯酒為歲祠，因泮凍，秋涸凍，冬塞禱祠。

translations.text: In spring they used dried meat and wine for the annual sacrifice, when the ice broke up; in autumn when water dried up; in winter for blocked prayers and sacrifices.

sentences.zh: 其牲用牛犢各一，牢具珪幣各異。

translations.text: Their sacrificial animals used one calf each, with varying pens, jade, and silk.

Therefore, east of Xiao, five famous mountains and two great rivers were sacrificed to. Called Tai Shi. Tai Shi is Mount Song. Mount Heng, Mount Tai, Mount Kuaiji, Mount Xiang. Rivers called Ji, called Huai. In spring they used dried meat and wine for the annual sacrifice, when the ice broke up; in autumn when water dried up; in winter for blocked prayers and sacrifices. Their sacrificial animals used one calf each, with varying pens, jade, and silk.

sentences.zh: 自華以西，名山七，名川四。

translations.text: West of Mount Hua, seven famous mountains and four famous rivers.

sentences.zh: 曰華山，薄山。

translations.text: Called Mount Hua, Mount Bo.

sentences.zh: 薄山者，衰山也。

translations.text: Mount Bo is Mount Wei.

sentences.zh: 岳山，岐山，吳岳，鴻冢，瀆山。

translations.text: Mount Yue, Mount Qi, Mount Wu, Mount Hongzhong, Mount Du.

sentences.zh: 瀆山，蜀之汶山。

translations.text: Mount Du is Shu's Mount Min.

sentences.zh: 水曰河，祠臨晉；

translations.text: Rivers called the Yellow River, sacrificed at Linjin;

sentences.zh: 沔，祠漢中；

translations.text: Mian, sacrificed at Hanzhong;

sentences.zh: 湫淵，祠朝那；

translations.text: Jiao Abyss, sacrificed at Zhaona;

sentences.zh: 江水，祠蜀。

translations.text: Yangtze River, sacrificed at Shu.

sentences.zh: 亦春秋泮涸禱塞，如東方名山川；

translations.text: Also in spring they break up ice, in autumn dry up water, in winter blocked prayers and sacrifices, like the eastern famous mountains and rivers;

sentences.zh: 而牲牛犢牢具珪幣各異。

translations.text: and the sacrificial animals were calves, with varying pens, jade, and silk.

sentences.zh: 而四大冢鴻、岐、吳、岳，皆有嘗禾。

translations.text: And the four great tombs Hong, Qi, Wu, Yue, all had autumn grain sacrifices.

West of Mount Hua, seven famous mountains and four famous rivers. Called Mount Hua, Mount Bo. Mount Bo is Mount Wei. Mount Yue, Mount Qi, Mount Wu, Mount Hongzhong, Mount Du. Mount Du is Shu's Mount Min. Rivers called the Yellow River, sacrificed at Linjin; Mian, sacrificed at Hanzhong; Jiao Abyss, sacrificed at Zhaona; Yangtze River, sacrificed at Shu. Also in spring they break up ice, in autumn dry up water, in winter blocked prayers and sacrifices, like the eastern famous mountains and rivers; and the sacrificial animals were calves, with varying pens, jade, and silk. And the four great tombs Hong, Qi, Wu, Yue, all had autumn grain sacrifices.

sentences.zh: 陳寶節來祠。

translations.text: Chen Bao had seasonal sacrifices.

sentences.zh: 其河加有嘗醪。

translations.text: The Yellow River additionally had autumn wine sacrifices.

sentences.zh: 此皆在雍州之域，近天子之都，故加車一乘，騮駒四。

translations.text: These were all in Yong province's domain, near the Son of Heaven's capital, so they added one carriage, four sorrel horses.

Chen Bao had seasonal sacrifices. The Yellow River additionally had autumn wine sacrifices. These were all in Yong province's domain, near the Son of Heaven's capital, so they added one carriage, four sorrel horses.

sentences.zh: 霸、產、長水、灃、澇、涇、渭皆非大川，以近咸陽，盡得比山川祠，而無諸加。

translations.text: Ba, Chan, Changshui, Yong, Lao, Jing, Wei were not great rivers, but because they were near Xianyang, they all received mountain and river sacrifices, without additional offerings.
Ba, Chan, Changshui, Yong, Lao, Jing, Wei were not great rivers, but because they were near Xianyang, they all received mountain and river sacrifices, without additional offerings.

sentences.zh: 汧、洛二淵，鳴澤、蒲山、嶽胥山之屬，為小山川，亦皆歲禱塞泮涸祠，禮不必同。

translations.text: The two abysses of Qian and Luo, Mingze, Pushan, Yuexushan and others were small mountains and rivers, and all had annual prayers and sacrifices for blockages, ice breaking, and water drying, but the rituals were not necessarily the same.

The two abysses of Qian and Luo, Mingze, Pushan, Yuexushan and others were small mountains and rivers, and all had annual prayers and sacrifices for blockages, ice breaking, and water drying, but the rituals were not necessarily the same.

sentences.zh: 而雍有日、月、參、辰、南北斗、熒惑、太白、歲星、填星、［辰星］、二十八宿、風伯、雨師、四海、九臣、十四臣、諸布、諸嚴、諸逑之屬，百有餘廟。

translations.text: Yong had more than a hundred temples for the sun, moon, Can, Shen, northern and southern dippers, Yinghuo, Taibai, Suixing, Tianshen, the twenty-eight constellations, wind lord, rain master, four seas, nine ministers, fourteen ministers, various spreading spirits, various strict spirits, various seeking spirits, and others.

sentences.zh: 西亦有數十祠。

translations.text: The west also had several dozen sacrifices.

sentences.zh: 於湖有周天子祠。

translations.text: At the lake there was a temple for the Zhou Son of Heaven.

sentences.zh: 於下邽有天神。

translations.text: At Xia Gui there was a heaven spirit.

sentences.zh: 灃、滈有昭明、天子辟池。

translations.text: Yong and Chen had Zhao Ming and the Son of Heaven's secluded pool.

sentences.zh: 於（社）［杜］、亳有三社主之祠、壽星祠；

translations.text: At Du and Bo there were sacrifices to the three altar lords and the longevity star;

sentences.zh: 而雍菅廟亦有杜主。

translations.text: and Yong's Jian temple also had a Du lord.

sentences.zh: 杜主，故周之右將軍，其在秦中，最小表之神者。

translations.text: The Du lord was formerly Zhou's right general, and among Qin spirits, he was the least significant.

sentences.zh: 各以歲時奉祠。

translations.text: Each was sacrificed to according to the seasons.

Yong had more than a hundred temples for the sun, moon, Can, Shen, northern and southern dippers, Yinghuo, Taibai, Suixing, Tianshen, the twenty-eight constellations, wind lord, rain master, four seas, nine ministers, fourteen ministers, various spreading spirits, various strict spirits, various seeking spirits, and others. The west also had several dozen sacrifices. At the lake there was a temple for the Zhou Son of Heaven. At Xia Gui there was a heaven spirit. Yong and Chen had Zhao Ming and the Son of Heaven's secluded pool. At Du and Bo there were sacrifices to the three altar lords and the longevity star; and Yong's Jian temple also had a Du lord. The Du lord was formerly Zhou's right general, and among Qin spirits, he was the least significant. Each was sacrificed to according to the seasons.

sentences.zh: 唯雍四畤上帝為尊，其光景動人民唯陳寶。

translations.text: Only Yong's four altars to the Supreme Deity were most honored, and what moved the people most was Chen Bao.

sentences.zh: 故雍四畤，春以為歲禱，因泮凍，秋涸凍，冬塞祠，五月嘗駒，及四仲之月（祠若）月祠，［若］陳寶節來一祠。

translations.text: Therefore Yong's four altars: in spring they made annual prayers, when ice broke up; in autumn when water dried; in winter for blocked sacrifices; in the fifth month they tasted colts; and in the four mid-months they sacrificed if it was the month, and if Chen Bao's season came, they sacrificed once.

sentences.zh: 春夏用騂，秋冬用駵。

translations.text: In spring and summer they used red horses, in autumn and winter they used black horses.

sentences.zh: 畤駒四匹，木禺龍欒車一駟，木禺車馬一駟，各如其帝色。

translations.text: Altar colts were four horses each, wooden dragon-ornamented carriages one team, wooden carriages and horses one team each, each matching their emperor's color.

sentences.zh: 黃犢羔各四，珪幣各有數，皆生瘞埋，無俎豆之具。

translations.text: Yellow calves and lambs four each, jade and silk each had numbers, all buried alive, without sacrificial stands and vessels.

sentences.zh: 三年一郊。

translations.text: Once every three years for suburban sacrifices.

sentences.zh: 秦以冬十月為歲首，故常以十月上宿郊見，通權火，拜於咸陽之旁，而衣上白，其用如經祠云。

translations.text: Qin made the tenth month of winter the year's beginning, so they constantly used the tenth month to lodge at the altar and see the suburban sacrifice, passed through Quan fire, bowed beside Xianyang, and wore upper white, their usage was like the regular sacrifices.

sentences.zh: 西畤、畦畤，祠如其故，上不親往。

translations.text: The western altar and qi altar were sacrificed to as before, the emperor did not personally go.

Only Yong's four altars to the Supreme Deity were most honored, and what moved the people most was Chen Bao. Therefore Yong's four altars: in spring they made annual prayers, when ice broke up; in autumn when water dried; in winter for blocked sacrifices; in the fifth month they tasted colts; and in the four mid-months they sacrificed if it was the month, and if Chen Bao's season came, they sacrificed once. In spring and summer they used red horses, in autumn and winter they used black horses. Altar colts were four horses each, wooden dragon-ornamented carriages one team, wooden carriages and horses one team each, each matching their emperor's color. Yellow calves and lambs four each, jade and silk each had numbers, all buried alive, without sacrificial stands and vessels. Once every three years for suburban sacrifices. Qin made the tenth month of winter the year's beginning, so they constantly used the tenth month to lodge at the altar and see the suburban sacrifice, passed through Quan fire, bowed beside Xianyang, and wore upper white, their usage was like the regular sacrifices. The western altar and qi altar were sacrificed to as before, the emperor did not personally go.

sentences.zh: 諸此祠皆太祝常主，以歲時奉祠之。

translations.text: All these sacrifices were constantly overseen by the grand invocator, who sacrificed to them according to the seasons.

sentences.zh: 至如他名山川諸鬼及八神之屬，上過則祠，去則已。

translations.text: As for other famous mountains, rivers, various ghosts, and the eight spirits, when the emperor passed by he sacrificed, when he left he stopped.

sentences.zh: 郡縣遠方神祠者，民各自奉祠，不領於天子之祝官。

translations.text: Sacrifices to gods of distant commanderies and counties were maintained by the people themselves, not overseen by the Son of Heaven's invocator officials.

sentences.zh: 祝官有祕祝，即有菑祥，輒祝祠移過於下。

translations.text: The invocator officials had secret prayers, and when there were calamities or good omens, they immediately prayed and transferred them downward.

All these sacrifices were constantly overseen by the grand invocator, who sacrificed to them according to the seasons. As for other famous mountains, rivers, various ghosts, and the eight spirits, when the emperor passed by he sacrificed, when he left he stopped. Sacrifices to gods of distant commanderies and counties were maintained by the people themselves, not overseen by the Son of Heaven's invocator officials. The invocator officials had secret prayers, and when there were calamities or good omens, they immediately prayed and transferred them downward.

sentences.zh: 漢興，高祖之微時，嘗殺大蛇。

translations.text: When Han arose, during Gaozu's humble times, he once killed a large snake.

sentences.zh: 有物曰：「蛇，白帝子也，而殺者赤帝子。」

translations.text: There was a voice that said: 'The snake is the White Emperor's son, but the killer is the Red Emperor's son.'

sentences.zh: 高祖初起，禱豐枌榆社。

translations.text: When Gaozu first rose up, he prayed at the Fengfen Yu Altar.

sentences.zh: 徇沛，為沛公，則祠蚩尤，釁鼓旗。

translations.text: When he toured Pei, became Duke of Pei, he sacrificed to Chi You, smeared blood on drums and flags.

sentences.zh: 遂以十月至灞上，與諸侯平咸陽，立為漢王。

translations.text: He then arrived at Bashang in the tenth month, pacified Xianyang with the feudal lords, and was established as King of Han.

sentences.zh: 因以十月為年首，而色上赤。

translations.text: Therefore he made the tenth month the year's beginning, and took red as the superior color.

When Han arose, during Gaozu's humble times, he once killed a large snake. There was a voice that said: 'The snake is the White Emperor's son, but the killer is the Red Emperor's son.' When Gaozu first rose up, he prayed at the Fengfen Yu Altar. When he toured Pei, became Duke of Pei, he sacrificed to Chi You, smeared blood on drums and flags. He then arrived at Bashang in the tenth month, pacified Xianyang with the feudal lords, and was established as King of Han. Therefore he made the tenth month the year's beginning, and took red as the superior color.

sentences.zh: 二年，東擊項籍而還入關，問：「故秦時上帝祠何帝也？」

translations.text: In the second year, he attacked Xiang Ji eastward and returned, entering the passes, asked: 'What emperor did the former Qin sacrifice to the Supreme Deity?'

sentences.zh: 對曰：「四帝，有白、青、黃、赤帝之祠。」

translations.text: They answered: 'Four emperors, there were sacrifices to the White, Blue, Yellow, Red emperors.'

sentences.zh: 高祖曰：「吾聞天有五帝，而有四，何也？」

translations.text: Gaozu said: 'I have heard heaven has five emperors, but there are four, why is that?'

sentences.zh: 莫知其說。

translations.text: No one knew the explanation.

sentences.zh: 於是高祖曰：「吾知之矣，乃待我而具五也。」

translations.text: Therefore Gaozu said: 'I understand it now, they were waiting for me to complete the five.'

sentences.zh: 乃立黑帝祠，命曰北畤。

translations.text: He then established the Black Emperor sacrifice, named it the Northern Altar.

sentences.zh: 有司進祠，上不親往。

translations.text: The officials conducted the sacrifice, the emperor did not personally go.

sentences.zh: 悉召故秦祝官，復置太祝、太宰，如其故儀禮。

translations.text: He summoned all the former Qin invocator officials, restored the grand invocator and grand steward, following their former ceremonies and rituals.

sentences.zh: 因令縣為公社。

translations.text: He ordered the counties to establish public altars.

sentences.zh: 下詔曰：「吾甚重祠而敬祭。

translations.text: He issued an edict saying: 'I greatly value sacrifices and respect offerings.

sentences.zh: 今上帝之祭及山川諸神當祠者，各以其時禮祠之如故。」

translations.text: Now the sacrifices to the Supreme Deity and the various mountain and river spirits that should be sacrificed to, each will be sacrificed to according to their times and rituals as before.'

In the second year, he attacked Xiang Ji eastward and returned, entering the passes, asked: 'What emperor did the former Qin sacrifice to the Supreme Deity?' They answered: 'Four emperors, there were sacrifices to the White, Blue, Yellow, Red emperors.' Gaozu said: 'I have heard heaven has five emperors, but there are four, why is that?' No one knew the explanation. Therefore Gaozu said: 'I understand it now, they were waiting for me to complete the five.' He then established the Black Emperor sacrifice, named it the Northern Altar. The officials conducted the sacrifice, the emperor did not personally go. He summoned all the former Qin invocator officials, restored the grand invocator and grand steward, following their former ceremonies and rituals. He ordered the counties to establish public altars. He issued an edict saying: 'I greatly value sacrifices and respect offerings. Now the sacrifices to the Supreme Deity and the various mountain and river spirits that should be sacrificed to, each will be sacrificed to according to their times and rituals as before.'

sentences.zh: 後四歲，天下已定，詔御史，令豐謹治枌榆社，常以四時春以羊彘祠之。

translations.text: Four years later, when the realm was already settled, he commanded the censor to order Feng to carefully maintain the Fen Yu Altar, constantly sacrificing to it in the four seasons, in spring using pigs and sheep.

sentences.zh: 令祝官立蚩尤之祠於長安。

translations.text: He ordered the invocator officials to establish Chi You's sacrifice in Chang'an.

sentences.zh: 長安置祠祝官、女巫。

translations.text: Chang'an established invocator officials and female shamans.

sentences.zh: 其梁巫，祠天、地、天社、天水、房中、堂上之屬；

translations.text: The Liang shamans sacrificed to heaven, earth, heavenly altar, heavenly water, inner chambers, halls above, and others;

sentences.zh: 晉巫，祠五帝、東君、雲中［君］、司命、巫社、巫祠、族人、先炊之屬；

translations.text: the Jin shamans sacrificed to the five emperors, eastern lord, cloud middle lord, destiny master, shaman altar, shaman temple, clansmen, first cooks, and others;

sentences.zh: 秦巫，祠社主、巫保、族纍之屬；

translations.text: the Qin shamans sacrificed to the altar lord, shaman protector, clan multitudes, and others;

sentences.zh: 荊巫，祠堂下、巫先、司命、施糜之屬；

translations.text: the Jing shamans sacrificed to hall below, shaman ancestors, destiny master, spreading spirits, and others;

sentences.zh: 九天巫，祠九天：皆以歲時祠宮中。

translations.text: the nine heaven shamans sacrificed to the nine heavens: all sacrificed in the palace according to the seasons.

sentences.zh: 其河巫祠河於臨晉，而南山巫祠南山秦中。

translations.text: The river shamans sacrificed to the river at Linjin, and the southern mountain shamans sacrificed to the southern mountains in Qin central.

sentences.zh: 秦中者，二世皇帝。

translations.text: Qin central refers to the Second Emperor.

sentences.zh: 各有時（月）［日］。

translations.text: Each had its time and day.

Four years later, when the realm was already settled, he commanded the censor to order Feng to carefully maintain the Fen Yu Altar, constantly sacrificing to it in the four seasons, in spring using pigs and sheep. He ordered the invocator officials to establish Chi You's sacrifice in Chang'an. Chang'an established invocator officials and female shamans. The Liang shamans sacrificed to heaven, earth, heavenly altar, heavenly water, inner chambers, halls above, and others; the Jin shamans sacrificed to the five emperors, eastern lord, cloud middle lord, destiny master, shaman altar, shaman temple, clansmen, first cooks, and others; the Qin shamans sacrificed to the altar lord, shaman protector, clan multitudes, and others; the Jing shamans sacrificed to hall below, shaman ancestors, destiny master, spreading spirits, and others; the nine heaven shamans sacrificed to the nine heavens: all sacrificed in the palace according to the seasons. The river shamans sacrificed to the river at Linjin, and the southern mountain shamans sacrificed to the southern mountains in Qin central. Qin central refers to the Second Emperor. Each had its time and day.

sentences.zh: 其後二歲，或曰周興而邑邰，立后稷之祠，至今血食天下。

translations.text: Two years later, some said that when Zhou arose they settled in Tai, established Hou Ji's sacrifice, and to this day receive blood sacrifices throughout the realm.

sentences.zh: 於是高祖制詔御史：「其令郡國縣立靈星祠，常以歲時祠以牛。」

translations.text: Therefore Gaozu issued an edict to the censor: 'Order the commanderies, kingdoms, and counties to establish the spirit star sacrifice, constantly sacrificing to it with oxen according to the seasons.'

Two years later, some said that when Zhou arose they settled in Tai, established Hou Ji's sacrifice, and to this day receive blood sacrifices throughout the realm. Therefore Gaozu issued an edict to the censor: 'Order the commanderies, kingdoms, and counties to establish the spirit star sacrifice, constantly sacrificing to it with oxen according to the seasons.'

sentences.zh: 高祖十年春，有司請令縣常以春（三）［二］月及（時）臘祠社稷以羊豕，民里社各自財以祠。

translations.text: In Gaozu's tenth year spring, the officials requested to order the counties to constantly sacrifice to the altars and grains in spring's second month and at year's end with pigs and sheep, and the village altars would each use their own wealth for sacrifices.

sentences.zh: 制曰：「可。」
